The United States had reportedly sought Aswat's arrest earlier while he was in South Africa, but he slipped away through Botswana to Zambia.

In the investigation into the July 7 attacks in London, the police had reportedly initially sought to trace 20 phone calls made by Aswat to establish whether he was linked to the London bombings, but the police here have since played down the possibility of a connection.

The investigation has thrown up many theories, one of them of a link -- as reported in British newspapers on Sunday -- to two Moroccans suspected as Qaida members who were shot dead in Saudi Arabia earlier this year.
The men were identified in news reports as Abdulkarim el-Mejjati and Younis al-Hayyari.
It is under investigation by both your security forces and our security forces, he said.
News agencies also quoted the Saudi foreign minister, Saud al-Faisal, as saying in Riyadh that British and Saudi intelligence officials routinely exchange information.
I'm sure there is some information that may be linked to events in England, he said.
They have also passed some information that was important to some of the incidents here.

The theories surfaced as Britain brought formal charges against Yasin Hassan Omar, a 24-year-old Somali who was arrested in Birmingham after the July 21 bombing attempts and who is accused of conspiracy to commit murder and possession of explosives.
Omar was the first of the main suspects to be charged formally.
He is to appear in court on Monday.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
The measures could include closing some mosques, banning organizations and deporting some clerics.

She introduced herself to the audience of up to 2,000 mainly young people by saying the clothes she was wearing -- red and black scarves and a long dark blue dress -- were those she wore in captivity, not the orange coveralls given to detainees at the American facilities at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

It is time to stand up together.
Resistance is our duty.
If you want to make war against Islam," she warned Blair, "I am ready."
However, others, like Sheik Shabir Ally, a cleric from Canada, expressed different views.

And people are using sentences from the Quran out of context.
People have to be careful.
Taje Mustafa, a spokesman for Hizb ut-Tahrir, an organization Blair said he would ban, said: Tony Blair wants to divide the Muslim community into two parts -- into extremists and moderates.
But who is extremist and who is moderate?
At a news conference on Friday, Blair warned that Islamic militants inciting hatred and violence could be deported or held under a form of house arrest known as control orders.
Several Muslims who offered fiery remarks to television interviewers last week are under investigation to determine whether they committed offenses, including treason, in making their statements.
One is Omar Bakri Mohammed, a Syrian-born cleric who led a group called Al Muhajiroun -- now said to have been disbanded -- whose successor organizations Blair also wishes to outlaw.
The debate over militant language extends beyond Muslims.
KATRINA-ADVISORY-NYT
Editors, The New York Times plans a package of stories on Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath for release Thursday, Sept. 1.
KATRINA-RDP (New Orleans) -- A ledeall as estimates of the death toll from the storm and flooding continue to rise.
New Orleans officials try to move out anyone remaining in the city, including a massive relocation of the 20,000 plus refugees at the Superdome, who will be relocated to the Astrodome in Houston.
By Robert D.McFadden, Joseph B. Treaster, Felicity Barringer and others.
With photos and graphics.
An early lede, KATRINA, has moved.
KATRINA-FEDS (Washington) -- A ledeall from Washington.

The Bush administration began mounting a massive federal response on Wednesday to the devastating damage from Hurricane Katrina, deploying active duty military forces to the Gulf Coast to help with rescue and relief missions, authorizing the release of oil from the nation's strategic reserve to blunt the economic effects of the storm and dispatching growing quantities of food, water and medical supplies to the region.

President Bush returned to the White House from his vacation home in Texas to oversee the effort, getting a view of the damage en route as Air Force One altered its route to take him on a low-altitude pass over New Orleans and other stricken areas in Louisiana and Mississippi.
He will speak later in the Rose Garden.
By Richard W.Stevenson.
With

BUSH-ASSESS (Washington) -- Not since he sat silently in a classroom in a Sarasota, Fla., elementary school as the World Trade Center burned and collapsed a thousand miles away has President Bush faced a test quite like the one he returned to Washington to confront on Wednesday afternoon.
But when the enemy is nature and the scene is spread over several states, the challenge is quite different.

And to complicate matters, Bush confronts this disaster at a time that his political capital is depleted, his poll ratings are at record lows and even some in the White House worry that Bush, on the last days of a month-long vacation, appeared out of position -- and perhaps too detached from the disaster unfolding along the Gulf Coast.
A news analysis by David E.Sanger.
KATRINA-EVACUATE (New York) -- A rescue effort is under way to move the refugees from the Superdome to the Astrodome in Houston.
Officials hope to also move anyone else still remaining in the city.
By Joseph B.Treaster.
KATRINA-RESCUE (Gulfort, Miss.) -- A report on the massive airlift rescue going on in Mississippi where -- it turns out -- people have been stranded on rooftops and islands for three days.
By Shaila Dewan and Kate Zernike.

KATRINA-LAWLESS (Dateline TK) -- With law officers and National Guardsmen focused on saving lives, looters around the city spent another day brazenly ransacking stores for food, clothing, appliances -- and guns.
(Summary from wires) By Felicity Barringer, Joseph B. Treaster and Jere Longman.
From the Business Desk:
KATRINA-OIL (Undated) -- For the first time since the 1970s, gasoline lines reappeared in some corners of the country.

Three days after Hurricane Katrina dealt a devastating blow to the nation's largest energy hub, the worst-case scenario was quickly becoming a reality: Oil prices surging to stratospheric levels, services stations running out of gasoline, drivers waiting in line for dwindling supplies.
The storm, which submerged New Orleans as it slammed into the Gulf Coast, also impaired the country's energy industry from Houston to New England.
Around the region, in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, power supplies were down, refineries went underwater, and nearly two dozens offshore platforms were submerged.
The impact is likely to be widely felt across the nation for months.
By Jad Mouawad, Simon Romero and Vikas Bajaj.
With photo and graphic.

KATRINA-TELECOMS (Undated) -- A look at the communications situation in the disaster area: status of telephone lines, cell-phone and text-messaging service; how people are getting information in and out, and how companies are going about restoring service.
By Ken Belson.
KATRINA-CARGO (Undated) -- New Orleans was a key port for many raw materials needed to run the economy -- steel, fruits and vegetables, and chemicals.
By Alexei Barrionuevo and Melanie Warner.
KATRINA-POWER-LINES (Undated) -- As utilities in the South begin the task of rebuilding power lines, companies from other regions of the country mobilize to help.
By Barnaby J. Feder and Jennifer Boyot.
From the Culture Desk:
NEW-ORLEANS-MUSIC (Undated) -- A Critic's Notebook: New Orleans is a legendary center of American music.
It's thought of as a jazz hotspot -- the birthplace of both Dixieland and Wynton Marsalis -- and that's all it once was.
The contemporary New Orleans music scene is at least as important for hip-hop as it is for jazz.
What it mostly is is singular: a place where musicians play a gig in one club at 7:30, cross the street to play in another club at 9, then cross again to play a third club at 11.
By Ben Ratliff.

KATRINA-TV (Undated) -- For the broadcast networks and cable news channels, the logistics of covering Katrina have been more difficult than covering Iraq or even the recent tsunami because of the almost complete lack of available power.
By Bill Carter.
From the Science desk:
KATRINA-HOSPITALS (Undated) -- Flooded and otherwise damaged hospitals are overwhelmed.
How governments at all levels are responding to the health emergency.
By Alan Feuer and Lawrence K.Altman.
KATRINA-LEVEES (Undated) -- More on how the two big levees breached and what must be done to fix them.
Were they allowed to deteriorate needlessly? By Andrew C. Revkin, Cornelia Dean and Chris Drew.
KATRINA-WATER (Undated) -- "Toxic gumbo": A look at what's in the water covering much of New Orleans, and what sort of residue it will leave when things finally dry out.
By Kenneth Chang.
KATRINA-COPING (Undated) -- The psychological fallout.
Coping with floods is usually more difficult than coping with other natural disasters.
How and why.
By Benedict Carey.
And from the Style Desk's Home section:

KATRINA-WARD (Washington) -- Sitting safely in Washington, I am watching harrowing footage shot from helicopters above the Ninth Ward of New Orleans, submerged under 14 feet of water when the Mississippi thundered through the breached levee at the Industrial Canal, destroying everything in its swirling waters.
My home is there, a West Indian-style plantation house built in 1826, standing as an ancient relic amid a maze of wooden houses a century younger.
Some are classic bungalows, but most are distinctly New Orleans building types, with fanciful names like shotguns and camelbacks.
I watch as a neighbor is rescued from his rooftop, the water swirling only a few feet below him.
Dazed, he has just emerged from his attic, wriggling through a hole he hacked in the roof, to be swooped up on a swinging rope.
He is safe.
Scores of others aren't.

Tuesday night the mayor reported bodies floating through the streets of the Ninth Ward, bodies of the poor blacks and whites, creoles of color, and sprinkling of artists of every type who inhabit this deepest-dyed old New Orleans neighborhood.
By S. Frederick Starr.

KATRINA-ROOFS (Undated) -- On Tuesday night, Reed Kroloff, the dean of the architecture school at Tulane University in New Orleans, was holed up in a hotel in Houston watching footage of his city -- and possible his century-old Victorian house -- being walloped by Hurricane Katrina.
The roof might be gone, or a giant oak tree has crashed through a window, Kroloff said in a phone interview.
Like many residents of New Orleans who fled, Kroloff was imagining the worst, and with good reason.
Although he had tried to secure his house by covering his windows and French doors with plywood, and closing shutters with bag ties, strong winds can wreak havoc with such measures in seconds.
Structural engineers say roofs are weak spots when it comes to high winds because when they hit a house an uplift is created that can tear away shingles and separate the roof from the rafters.
Winds also create horizontal pressure, called shear.
If a house isn't properly secured, the combination of uplift and shear can sometimes tip the house over.
By Ernest Beck.

FOR TUESDAY AMs Here are today's top news stories from The New York Times News Service for AMs of Tuesday, Sept. 6.
For the latest photos and graphics from The New York Times, go to www.nytimages.com.
HURRICANE KATRINA ("a" code) KATRINA-RDP (Undated) -- A ledeall.
A week after the storm, a definitive death toll remained elusive, but New Orleans Mayor Ray Nagin warned on NBC's "Today" that "it wouldn't be unreasonable to have 10,000" dead.
Residents of one hard hit area of New Orleans, Jefferson Parish, were allowed to re-enter the area to assess what if anything is left of their former lives.
President Bush began his second trip to the region since the storm hit, landing in Baton Rouge late in the morning to start another inspection tour and consultations with federal and local officials.

At two of the city's damaged levees, engineers continued making repairs that would allow pumps to begin draining the floodwaters, and officials said that fewer than 10,000 people remained in the city, based on aerial reconnaissance.
By Clyde Haberman, Alex Berenson and others.
KATRINA-BUSH (Dateline TK) -- President Bush returns to the Gulf Coast to tour the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina.
By Elisabeth Bumiller.

KATRINA-CLINTON (Washington) -- Former President Bill Clinton has taken on yet another role for the Bush administration -- this time, fund-raising for the hurricane victims -- which invites an obvious political question: Have the Bushes co-opted Clinton?

In his latest role as Bush envoy at large, Clinton appears to be struggling to balance his support for the administration's efforts with his own opinions, which no doubt include at least some criticism of the government's rescue performance in hurricane disaster.
And by keeping the former president close at hand, how might it affect the role of his wife , Sen.Hillary Clinton?
By Adam Nagourney.
KATRINA-JEFFERSON (Metairie, La.) -- Residents of hard-hit Jefferson parish are being allowed back home for the first time to see what they lost and who is dead.
By Jodi Wilgoren.
KATRINA-DELTA (Venice, La.) -- A look at Venice and the surrounding peninsula of hard-to-reach coastal communities.
By Dan Barry.
KATRINA-BARBOUR (Dateline TK) -- A look at Mississippi's Gov.Haley Barbour and his handling of the storm relief effort in his state and the political storm surrounding the Bush administration.
By Michael Cooper.

KATRINA-POLICE (New Orleans) -- The voices of overworked, overwhelmed and stressed members of the New Orleans police department, including a lieutenant who was with an officer who committed suicide while on hurricane relief duty.
They are tired, frustrated and angry, contending that they kept the city together during the darkest days of the storm and that FEMA workers and military personnel are getting all the credit.
By Joseph B.Treaster.
KATRINA-TEXAS (Galveston, Texas) -- A wider look at the response by the state of Texas to the hurricane disaster.
In Galveston, people are being brought in on navy ships.
In Huntsville, site of the state's death row prison, a shelter is taking shape for refugees.
(Editors, the scene at the Astrodome in Houston, plus the arrival of ex-Presidents Bush and Clinton to begin fund-raising efforts may be included in this article or broken out into a separate piece.
) By Simon Romero, Ralph Blumenthal and John M.Broder.
KATRINA-ORLEANS (New York) -- The scene in New Orleans.
By Jere Longman.
KATRINA-MARINES (Dateline TK) -- Embedded with the Marines on hurricane recovery duty.
By John Kifner.
KATRINA-IMMIG (Dateline TK) -- Like some many others here, Pedro, a landscaper from Chiapas, Mexico, is desperately trying to get out of Biloxi.
He wants to take his wife, Anna, who is eight months pregnant, to a cleaner and safer environment, wherever that might be.

Bran Dize, a prep cook from Spanishtown, Jamaica, near Kinston, worries that Hurricane Katrina may suddenly have made him an illegal immigrant, because, he said, his special "guest worker" visa requires him to work at a casino -- the Beau Rivage -- that, for all practical purposes, no longer exists.
By Ian Urbina.
KATRINA-BABIES (Undated) -- On a neo-natal unit where scores of babies were moved to after they were evacuated, without their parents, from New Orleans.
By Sewell Chan.
KATRINA-WELFARE (Baton Rouge, La.
) -- People seeking public assistance are having to stand in long lines to sign up for welfare benefits and food stamps.
And many are being asked to produce identification and other documents that were lost in the hurricane flood waters.
By Sewell Chan.
Editors, more stories related to Katrina are listed under Finance, below; and under Science, separately.

SUPREME COURT ("w" code) SCOTUS-APPOINT (Washington) -- A ledeall: President Bush nominated Judge John G.Roberts Jr.on Monday to replace Chief Justice William H.Rehnquist, whose death late Saturday opened a second vacancy on the Supreme Court and a new front in the ideological battle over the judiciary.

Senate leaders agreed Monday morning to delay by at least two days the start of Roberts's confirmation hearing, which had been set to begin on Tuesday, when he was being considered to succeed Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.
Now that Bush has nominated him for the chief justice's job, several Senate and Congressional leaders had asked that the hearings be delayed until after Rehnquist's funeral, which is Wednesday.
By Richard W.Stevenson.
SCOTUS-CHIEF (Washington) -- As a law clerk to William Rehnquist, John Roberts Jr.learned valuable lessons about how to be chief justice -- or, more precisely, how not to be chief justice.
Some reflections on the nature of the job.
By Linda Greenhouse.

SCOTUS-CONGRESS (Washington) -- A look at how the decision on Judge John B. Roberts Jr.affects the work on Capitol Hill, not only in resubmitting the nomination of Roberts as chief justice, but also preparing for a second confirmation hearing.
By David D.Kirkpartick.
BUSH-ASSESS (Washington) -- A look at President Bush's day and how, or whether, he regains at least some of his political footing.

He seized the initiative with his early-morning announcement on Judge John G. Roberts Jr, then promptly left for the Gulf Coast, no doubt hoping to overcome some of the harsh criticism he encountered after his Air Force One flyover and his first visit to parts of the hurricane-stricken area.
A news analysis by Todd S.Purdum.

The president spoke just after two dozen insurgents staged a brazen dawn raid on the heavily guarded offices of Iraq's Interior Ministry in Baghdad, killing two police officers and wounding five, and two British soldiers were killed by a bomb in southern Iraq.
By Robert F.Worth.

INDONESIA-CRASH (Jakarta) -- An Indonesian 737 passenger plane crashed into a crowded neighborhood shortly after takeoff in the northern city of Medan on Monday, killing 104 people aboard and 39 on the ground.
The operator, Mandala Airlines, said 13 people sitting in the rear survived the fire that engulfed the plane when it hit a busy road 500 yards from the airport in mid-morning.
By Jane Perlez.

LEBANON (Beirut, Lebanon) -- President Emile Lahoud, tainted by the arrests of his former security chiefs in the murder of Rafiq Hariri, creates a constitutional crisis by refusing to step down since there is no provision for impeachment in the Lebanese constitution.
By Hassan M.Fattah.

FRANCE-CHIRAC (Paris) -- President Jacques Chirac is in the hospital recovering from what doctors describe as a minor condition affecting his sight, but the French are already writing his political epitaph.

Though he has two years left in his term and has left open the possibility that he might run again, the media, political opponents and even his most loyal allies are acting as if he were already gone.
Strictly speaking, nothing has happened, read an editorial in the conservative daily Le Figaro.
But everyone feels somehow that something has tipped over.
By Craig S.Smith.

KOSOVO (Timisoara, Romania) -- The president of the U.N. administered province of Kosovo, Ibrahim Rugova, 61 conceded on Monday that he was suffering from lung cancer, raising questions about his participation in negotiations on the future of the region scheduled to begin this fall.
Despite the seriousness of the diagnosis, Rugova gave no indication that he planned to step down.
By Nicholas Wood.

AFGHAN (Kabul, Afghanistan) -- Afghan and American forces mounted an operation into a remote mountainous district of southern Afghanistan in pursuit of a group of insurgents and killed 13 suspected Taliban and detained over 40 people, Afghan and American officials said Monday.
By Carlotta Gall.
FINANCIAL ("f" code) TOYOTA-HYBRIDS (Tokyo) -- As gasoline prices soar to record levels, the Japanese automaker has a new strategy to put a hybrid in every American garage.
By James Brooke.
KATRINA-PHONES (Dateline TK) -- Scenes from the Mississippi Gulf Coast on repair missions by BellSouth crews camped out in a tent city.
BellSouth is the main telecom carrier for storm-ravaged Louisiana and Mississippi.
By Ken Belson.
KATRINA-ELECTRICITY (Dateline TK) -- An update on Entergy's efforts to restore power to New Orleans and other storm-stricken areas.
By Barnaby Feder.
KATRINA-GASOLINE (Undated) -- Two of the eight idled Gulf Cost refineries are in the process of coming back online after being out for a week.
Pipelines carrying refined product up the East Coast and to the Midwest are running about 90% of capacity.
Major oil companies continue to assess damage, with early reports showing that Chevron's and Conoco's refineries are the most damaged.
But all is not normal: Gasoline stations in the South and Midwest are still running low, just as families are returning from vacation en masse.
By Jad Mouawad and Vikas Bajaj.
EU-CHINA-TEXTILES (Undated) -- The European Union and China have reached an an agreement on textile imports.
By Paul Mellor in Burssels and Keith Bradsher in Hong Kong.
VW-LAYOFFS (Frankfurt, Germany) -- Volkswagen, Europe's biggest automaker, on Monday announced massive layoffs that analysts say could amount to 10,000 jobs lost.
VW is finally biting the bullet, and facing off with its powerful labor unions.
But the move comes just two weeks before crucial elections, and one day after Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder debated his opponent.

KAZAA-AUSTRALIA (Singapore) -- Australian court rules that Kazaa, the file-sharing service based there, violates Australian music copyrights and ordered the company to modify its software to help prevent it.
By Wayne Arnold.

KPMG-MARKETPLACE (Undated) -- The Justice Department's decision last week to accept a deferred prosecution of KPMG -- a decision that will allow the firm to escape without a criminal conviction if it behaves in the future -- highlights the current reality that the private enterprise system needs at least four major accounting firms.
By Floyd Norris.

JAPAN-CITIGROUP (Tokyo) -- Citigroup said on Monday that it planned to sell 230 billion yen, or $2.1 billion, of "samurai bonds" to Japanese investors, the largest effort by a foreign company to raise capital in Japan.
By Martin Fackler.
KOREA-SAMSUNG (Seoul, South Korea) -- Among the corporate success stories in South Korea over the last 50 years, Samsung Electronics dominates.

But at home, the Samsung group of companies, controlled by the family of Lee Kun Hee, the chairman of Samsung Electronics, faces a growing criticism of its ownership and control arrangements, as well as its handling of a looming generational change.

This attention on Samsung comes as regulators and legislators try to correct the imbalance between voting rights and the exercise of power by the founding families in the country's conglomerates, or chaebol, in an effort to protect shareholders.
By Donald Greenlees.

With KOREA-DAEWOO (Seoul, South Korea) -- The founder of Daewoo founder is behind bars and standing trial over currency violations and a vast accounting fraud perpetrated as his overstretched business empire collapsed in 1999 under $75 billion in debt.
And he is dividing Koreans between those who see him as a symbol of corrupt corporate practices and those who respect his contributions to South Korean industry.
By Donald Greenlees.

SWISS-BANKS (Geneva, Switzerland) -- UBS, Switzerland's largest bank, announced on Monday that it had sold its three private banks and its asset management unit to Julius Baer, the largest publicly traded private bank in Switzerland, for $4.6 billion.
But analysts said the sale was unlikely to spur more of the consolidation that some say is needed in Switzerland's crowded private banking industry.
By Tom Wright.

Itineraries BIZ-TRAVEL-HOLIDAY (Undated) -- A look at what's happening in the travel industry -- flight disruptions, cancellations, how it all plays out over the holiday weekend, with a part of the story looking ahead to the hurricane season and the potential for more bad news to come.
By Christopher Elliott.
BIZ-TRAVEL-PLANS (Undated) -- This fall is shaping up as one of the worst times for business travelers since 2001.
Aside from the disruptions of Katrina, United Airlines remains stuck in bankruptcy, three other carriers are teetering on the brink and prices are rising.
But employers are showing no inclination to cut back on travel schedules -- quite the contrary.
By Christopher Elliott.
BIZ-TRAVEL-ROAD (Undated) -- On the Road, the weekly business travel column.
By Joe Sharkey.

IRAQ, NOT KATRINA, MAY BE ACHILLES HEEL FOR BUSH

WASHINGTON - Many Democrats regard Hurricane Katrina as a political earthquake, an event destined to shake the Bush administration to its core, weakening the president's ability to promote his domestic agenda, and perhaps even prompting a reassessment of President Bush's character and abilities.
But the first round of public-opinion polls detected a political tremor, not an earthquake.
Indeed, some polls show that the hurricane has been a distraction from the longer-term issues plaguing Bush - principally the war in Iraq.
In other words, Bush may be weakened, and his agenda may be in trouble, but it's not just because of his handling of the hurricane.

And Democrats, who are already rushing to use the hurricane to promote their own priorities - from defeating the Supreme Court nominee, John G. Roberts Jr., to modifying the tough new bankruptcy law -might do just as well to focus on other issues.
An AP-Ipsos poll conducted from Sept. 6 to Sept. 8, more than a week after the hurricane, found that Bush's approval ratings had dropped to a weak 39 percent, from 42 percent in August.
But the percentage of Americans approving of Bush's performance on the hurricane - 46 percent - was much higher than the 37 percent approving of his handling of Iraq.
More people approved of Bush's efforts on the hurricane than of his work on the economy, health care, foreign policy, Social Security, or gas prices.
A Gallup poll conducted last week for CNN and USA Today was consistent with the AP-Ipsos findings.
It found that almost twice as many Americans (25 percent) had blamed state and local officials for problems with hurricane relief than had blamed Bush (13 percent).
The largest percentage, 38 percent, held no one responsible for the relief crisis.

However, a Pew Research Center poll asked the question in different terms last week, and found that a whopping 67 percent thought Bush could have done more to help the hurricane victims, even though some state and local officials shared the blame.
The key for Bush, said Pew Research Center director Andrew Kohut, will be whether perceptions of an inadequate response to the hurricane alter the way people view Bush - less firm in a crisis.
Not all of Bush's problems reside with Katrina, but he's been roundly criticized for the way he's handled the hurricane, said Kohut.
Bush is working hard to counter the perception that he hasn't paid enough attention to hurricane relief by making his third trip to New Orleans in two weeks.

His supporters hope the availability of other scapegoats - including the Democratic governor of Louisiana, Kathleen Blanco, and the Democratic mayor of New Orleans, C.Ray Nagin - take some focus off the president.
They also hope that people will be judicious in apportioning blame for what was, at bottom, a natural disaster.
By contrast, Bush's responsibility for the Iraq war has long been acknowledged and accepted by the president himself.
And the percentage of Americans who support the war has been dropping steadily all year, as has the percentage believing that the war has made the United States safer.

It's his war.
It's not going well.
It has his name on it.
After months of trying to agree on common goals, the Democrats in the House and Senate seem to have resigned themselves to criticizing Bush's policies - while saying little about their alternatives.
It seems likely that Katrina will continue to alter priorities in ways that could be beneficial to Democrats.
The Pew poll, for instance, found that for the first time since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, a majority believes that the president should concentrate on domestic issues, not foreign policy.
But the public doesn't need Democrats to tell them what went wrong with Bush's response to the disaster in New Orleans.
The public needs Democrats to offer fresh alternatives on the economy and security.
The public, at least according to polls, is ready and eager to think about new ideas.
The Democrats may not be.
Peter S. Canellos is the Globe's Washington bureau chief.
National Perspective is his weekly analysis of events in the capital and beyond.
BUSH ADMITS KATRINA MISTAKES
President Bush made a rare admission of error Tuesday as he accepted responsibility for the weak federal response to Hurricane Katrina and vowed to get to the bottom of what went wrong.

Bush, who belatedly cut short his summer vacation and returned to Washington after Katrina struck the Gulf Coast two weeks ago, planned to address the nation Thursday evening from New Orleans during his fourth visit to the stricken region.

Bush spoke in response to a reporter asking whether Americans, in light of the federal government's sluggish response to Katrina, should be concerned about whether Washington is prepared to handle another disaster or even a terrorist attack.
I want to know what went right and what went wrong, Bush said.

I want to know how to better cooperate with state and local government -- to be able to answer that very question that you asked:
Are we capable of dealing with a severe attack or another severe storm?
And it's in our national interest that we find out what went on so that we can better respond.
Even as he acknowledged problems, Bush praised Coast Guard and other rescue teams in the devastated area.

While still considerably lower than earlier estimates by local officials, Katrina's death toll, mainly from massive flooding after the hurricane passed, reached 423 in Louisiana on Tuesday, and 236 in Mississippi and elsewhere along the Gulf Coast.

During a tour of hurricane-stricken Mississippi, U.S. Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta said Katrina has caused the worst transportation disaster in American history, hamstringing movement of people and cargo in ports, on highways and along rivers.
Accountability at every level is critical, and leadership begins at the top.

A Senate committee, headed by Republican Sen.Susan Collins of Maine and Democratic Sen.Joe Lieberman of Connecticut, was scheduled today (Wednesday) to hold the first of what will likely be many congressional hearings on the Katrina response.

R.David Paulison, newly named head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said Bush told him during a phone conversation Monday evening that he "would have all the support of the federal government" to help Katrina survivors rebuild their lives and to aid in the ravaged area's reconstruction.
I can't deal with what happened in the last two weeks, but I can tell you, from this point forward, we are going to be focused on the victims of this hurricane, Paulison told reporters.

We've had a hurricane of unimaginable proportions, and we're going to deal with it.
We're going to get the people out of shelters, and we're going to move on and get them the help that they need.
We're going to focus on the victims out there of this hurricane from this point forward, and there'll be a time and place to sit down and look at those lessons learned, he said.
Now is the time to move forward, make sure they get the help they need and help they deserve.
Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff chose Paulison to replace Michael Brown, who resigned Monday after days of cascading criticism of FEMA's response to Katrina.
Chertoff had already recalled Brown to Washington and removed him from heading on-the-ground rescue and relief efforts in the Gulf Coast region.
Paulison has 30 years' experience in disaster rescue operations.
Among his previous jobs, he headed the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department and ran Dade County's emergency-management office, helping lead Florida's response to Hurricane Andrew in 1992.
The state named him fire chief of the year in 1993.

Landrieu joined Sen.David Vitter, a freshman Republican from Louisiana, on the Senate floor Tuesday in announcing plans by the state's congressional delegation to introduce a bill later this week to set up an independent reconstruction commission.
Sen.Edward Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, proposed last week that Congress create the Gulf Coast Redevelopment Authority.
It would be modeled after the Tennessee Valley Authority, which President Franklin Roosevelt and Congress established during the Depression to revitalize the seven-state Tennessee Valley region.
This has to be a partnership, because ultimately the communities are entitled to take responsibility and empower themselves.

Chertoff said he was sending teams of inspectors from his giant agency's inspector general's office to the area to oversee spending and contract awards from the nearly $62 billion in emergency aid authorized by Congress, a total expected to rise to as high as $200 billion.

The message that has gone out very clearly to everybody (is) that we're going to be efficient, we're going to cut through red tape, but we're not going to cut through the laws and the rules that govern ethics, Chertoff said.
Saying that "we are still in hurricane season," Chertoff also warned that the country could face new storms even as it tries to recover from Katrina.

They collected food, water, ice, generators, fuel and other necessities, and with no plan and with no budget, they got it to devastated areas -- in many cases over a week ahead of the bureaucrats, Vitter said.
GOVERNMENT TO INVESTIGATE KATRINA RELIEF EFFORT

The inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security said Tuesday his office has received allegations of fraud and waste in the multibillion-dollar relief programs linked to Hurricane Katrina and would investigate how no-bid contracts were awarded to several large, politically well-connected companies.

The inspector general, Richard L. Skinner, who serves as the department's internal watchdog, said in an interview that he intended to be "extremely aggressive" in monitoring the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which will receive most of the $62 billion in disaster-response funds approved by Congress last week.
FEMA, which is part of Homeland Security, was harshly criticized in recent months for mismanaging millions of dollars in relief funds for Hurricane Frances last year.

Skinner's remarks came as the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff; Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales; and Republican congressional leaders said Tuesday that they also were concerned about the potential for abuse, given the amount of federal money and private charity committed to the hurricane-relief effort.
We haven't suspended the laws that govern the way in which people have to behave ethically and legally.

Spokesmen at FEMA have been unwilling to provide details of the decision-making process that is being used to award contracts for the hurricane-relief program, nor have they identified the agency officials who are making the procurement decisions.

During the Bush administration, the agency's senior management has included several officials without significant experience in disaster relief, including its former director, Michael Brown, who resigned on Monday.
Skinner, a former acting inspector general of FEMA, would not discuss details of the allegations his office has received in recent days involving Katrina relief projects.

But he said he was dispatching about 30 investigators and auditors to Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama next week to "focus on prevention -- to prevent things from going wrong" in the way the disaster money is spent.

He said that his investigators would focus on several no-bid contracts awarded during the last two weeks to large, politically influential companies, including the Fluor Corp. of California, a major donor to the Republican Party, and the Shaw Group, based in Baton Rouge, La.
Shaw is a client of Joe M.Allbaugh, a consultant who is the former head of FEMA and was President Bush's campaign manager in 2000.

Another of Allbaugh's clients -- Kellogg Brown & Root, a subsidiary of Halliburton, the giant defense contractor once led by Vice President Dick Cheney -- is doing major repairs at Navy facilities along the Gulf Coast that were damaged by the hurricane.
That work is being done under a $500 million contract with the Defense Department.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM.)

He said his investigators would also closely monitor expenditures on the government-issued credit cards of Department of Homeland Security contracting officials involved in the hurricane-relief program.
Skinner said his office had acquired computer software that would allow his investigators to monitor the credit-card charges on a daily basis.
He added, "If we see a credit card purchase of $250,000, we would immediately find out whether it was appropriate."

In recognition of potential problems, the Office of Management and Budget announced Tuesday it was issuing new rules on use of the credit cards, requiring supervisors to identify which procurement officials could make use of the $250,000 limit and to set clear policies on which items could be purchased for the relief effort.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)
Under the $51.8 billion hurricane-relief bill approved by Congress last week, Skinner's office was provided with $15 million for investigations related to Hurricane Katrina.
Skinner's office produced a harshly critical audit earlier this year of FEMA's performance after Hurricane Frances struck Florida during the Labor Day weekend of 2004.
The audit questioned millions of dollars in federal payouts to residents of Miami-Dade County even though the county suffered little damage.
The audit found that more than $8 million was given to 4,300 people for temporary housing even though they had not asked for the money and most never left their homes.
The disaster agency paid out more than $720,000 to county residents to replace belongings that they claimed were damaged or destroyed, based on their word alone.
U.S. Rep.Robert Wexler, D-Fla., called at the time of the audit for Brown to resign as FEMA director.
EDITORIAL: FEMA NEEDS NEW LEADER, BUT ISSUE IS BIGGER THAN THAT
Michael Brown resigned Monday as director of an agency he appeared unqualified to lead, the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Someone with emergency services -- and hurricane -- experience now is filling the top FEMA post.
Brown was right in his departing statement that the focus should not be on him, but on FEMA.
And whatever happens at FEMA is of grave importance to southern Beaufort County.
Sooner or later, it will be our turn to look to FEMA as a lifeline, not a politically-charged news story.
Perhaps the president will speak to that issue in his planned -- and overdue -- address to the nation from Louisiana on Thursday.
Yes, a focus should be on FEMA. But remember, FEMA is the whipping boy every time a hurricane strikes.
We remember it from Hurricane Hugo, which hammered the Lowcountry in 1989.
And that was a storm not nearly as severe as Katrina.
Still, FEMA could not do enough to suit the understandably impatient and disgruntled hurricane victims.
Katrina seems to be telling the nation that there are disasters too big for FEMA, even under the best of leadership.
It is telling us there are disasters too big for governors and stricken county and municipal governments.
All of these governments play a vital role, of course.
And Katrina is showing how bad things can get when any link in the government chain is frail.

But it is time for this nation to recognize that it must sometimes -- and in a timely manner -- call on the organizations that truly are prepared, staffed, equipped and trained to handle such a large disaster.
That is the U.S. military.
The USS Bataan happened to be in the Gulf of Mexico and followed the hurricane to shore.
It was, as it turns out, a "first responder.

But it was not used to the fullest.
It offered medical and rescue capabilities.
It could produce 100,000 gallons of fresh water per day.
It has smaller vessels able to go ashore with supplies and doctors.
But that capability was not tapped fully when it was needed.
The nation instead saw mayhem at the New Orleans Superdome and convention center.
The Katrina problem has a solution.
America responded well to the tsunami, and it can respond well to a three-state, Category 4 hurricane.
Unfortunately, the nation is tripping over its own feet.
Hilton Head Island Packet editorial
BIRD FLU COULD KILL THOUSANDS IN WEEKS
If the dire predictions of an influenza pandemic come true, Minnesota's health officials expect 1.25 million state residents to become infected.
In a matter of days, a surge of patients would overwhelm the hospital system.
State government officials and hospitals, using emergency powers, would sort patients through triage, even moving them among regions of the state.
Still, each hospital bed in the state would have as many as five patients waiting to fill it, according to Minnesota emergency preparedness officials.
An estimated 20,000 people would die.
And it would all happen in four to eight weeks.
In Minnesota, as in other states, the preparation for a deadly influenza outbreak has been underway for many years, but planning went into high gear in 2001 after fears of an anthrax or other bioterrorism disaster.
The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, which had been criticized for dragging its feet on an avian flu response plan, could release a proposal next week, according to news reports.
Experts' concerns
They know that it spreads quickly among birds, and that it's deadly -- it's killed millions of chickens and other fowl throughout Asia since it first surfaced in Hong Kong in 1997.
In humans, the death toll is in the dozens.
So far, almost all the human victims had close contact with diseased animals, which means that it's not spreading from person to person.
But that could change.
In the worst-case scenario, the avian flu virus would come into contact with a flu strain that does pass easily from person to person.
That could happen if an individual becomes infected with both strains at the same time.
In that setting, it could morph into a new virus with the worst of all traits: deadly, fast, and transmissible by a sneeze or a handshake.
If that happens, the World Health Organization (WHO) estimated last year, as many as 100 million people could die.
Last week, a United Nations official upped it to 150 million.
Dr. Harry Hull, Minnesota's top public health official, said the avian flu virus presents a credible threat.
But he cautioned that the avian virus is not guaranteed to mutate into a dangerous human influenza virus.
It could just die out in birds, he said, or mutate into a form to which the human system learns how to adapt.
If that were the case, it would be more like SARS, which is relatively difficult to spread from person to person.
The once-feared SARS is now controlled by isolating infected patients.
The preparations for a global influenza epidemic are similar to the planning that must be done for most public health crises.
There's a lot of work being done," Hull said.

It is the same kind of questions involved with bioterrorism.
The question is, how do we take what we have available to make sure that the maximum number of people survive?" he said.
Minnesota's hospitals have signed regional compacts binding them to share resources and coordinate responses in the event of a major emergency.
There are 29 hospitals in the metropolitan pact.
All are linked through an emergency radio system and an Internet crisis communications network.

We used it here during the Katrina event to coordinate among the metropolitan hospitals and other regions in the state, putting together volunteers, said Mark Lappe, director of safety, security and emergency preparedness at Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis.
The hospitals would share equipment and staff, and admissions would be coordinated among all the hospitals.
If we exceed the capacity in the hospitals themselves, then we might set up an offsite hospital, an austere hospital site, to provide basic health care, said Lappe.
The austere -- or bare-bones -- hospital could be located in a school, auditorium or convention center, he said.
Fears about a catastrophic flu outbreak have waxed and waned in the medical world for years.
The same fears were cited in 1976 during the swine flu scare, when millions of Americans were inoculated against a terror that never materialized.
The big fear is that the world may face a repeat of the 1918 Spanish flu, which killed anywhere from 20 million to 50 million people in less than a year, including about 675,000 Americans.
That virus spread swiftly and easily and had a fearsome death rate -- about 5 percent.
Historians say that some victims woke up feeling well, got sick by noon and were dead by nightfall.
It was even too big for the word "epidemic.

Experts called it a pandemic -- a worldwide epidemic.
Two less-deadly flu pandemics struck in the 20th century -- the Asian flu in 1957-58 and the Hong Kong flu in 1968-69.
EDITORIAL:BIRD FLU AND THE 1918 PANDEMIC
The New York Times said in an editorial for Saturday, Oct. 8:
The worrisome news is that the 1918 virus appears to have jumped directly from birds to humans, and that the genetic changes that allowed it to do so are already beginning to appear in the avian strain, known as H5N1, which has killed large numbers of birds and about 60 people in four Asian countries.
The two most recent pandemics, in 1957 and 1968, were caused by human flu viruses that picked up some bird flu components.
Now it turns out that the far more lethal 1918 virus, which killed perhaps 20 million to 100 million people, was most likely an avian strain that jumped directly into humans.
That gives today's avian strain two routes to wreak havoc among humans.
It could either mix some of its genes with human influenza, like the 1957 and 1968 viruses, or it could mutate on its own to become easily transmissible among humans, like the 1918 virus.
So far, the avian virus has rarely jumped from birds to humans and seldom spread from one human to another.
But it may be traveling slowly down the same evolutionary path as the 1918 virus.
Two top federal health officials said that the H5N1 virus has already acquired five of the 10 genetic sequence changes associated with human-to-human transmission of the 1918 virus.
That does not necessarily mean that catastrophe is imminent.
Nobody knows how likely it is that further mutations will occur or how long the process may take.
The avian virus has been around for decades without turning into a monster.
The new findings offer promising leads to health officials who are concerned about preparing for a possible pandemic.
Scientists should be able to prepare a checklist of the most worrisome genetic changes so they can monitor the evolution of the avian flu virus and rush medical help to any area where it looks as if the virus is becoming more transmissible.
They may also be able to develop drugs and vaccines aimed at the most important genetic targets, thus allowing them to treat or even prevent influenza more effectively.
Nobody knows whether the avian strain now under the spotlight will become a bigger threat to humans.
But some day a potential pandemic strain will arrive.
The new findings could help develop tools to contain it.
THE FRONT LINES IN THE BATTLE AGAINST AVIAN FLU ARE RUNNING SHORT OF MONEY
As the Bush administration and Congress prepare to spend billions of dollars to improve America's ability to combat avian flu, crucial needs are being left unmet on the front lines of the world's defenses against the disease, in some cases for lack of a few million dollars, international health officials said Saturday.
When Vietnam began detecting the disease in chickens nearly two years ago, it initially slaughtered and burned every chicken within three miles of an infected fowl in an effort to prevent the spread of the disease.
Yielding to popular pressure, the government has steadily shrunk the culling radius.
Officials now kill only those birds in an infected household flock that do not die of the disease by themselves.
Birds from different households, even those only a few yards away and also at risk from the disease, are left untouched, Vietnamese officials said.
In Indonesia, a lack of money to compensate farmers for culled chickens prompted the government to announce last year a less expensive policy of vaccinating chickens.
One risk of such a strategy is that the virus will adapt and infect even unvaccinated chickens without causing symptoms of illness.
That makes it extremely difficult to keep live, infected chickens from being sold in markets.
Indonesian and Hong Kong health officials said this week that exactly this problem of chickens infected but without symptoms had been detected in Indonesia.
But the World Health Organization cautioned that more lab tests were needed, which takes time because of a shortage of staff and equipment.
The U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization has been trying since February to raise $100 million from donor nations to pay for veterinary services and diagnostic equipment to assess and slow the spread of avian flu in chickens and other fowl.
The FAO decided at the time not to ask for more money, to compensate farmers for the culling of their flocks, after concluding that donors would not be willing to contribute any more.
But so far, the organization has raised barely $30 million, leaving many veterinary needs unmet.
The $100 million figure is what we think is the minimum for what the countries in the region need immediately to contain the virus" and slow its spread, said Diderik De Vleeschauwer, the FAO's spokesman in Bangkok.
Eradication of the disease in birds is already impossible, he added, because it has become so widespread in Southeast Asia.

But containing the spread of the disease could reduce the opportunities for the virus to acquire the ability to pass easily from person to person, a requisite for the virus to cause a global pandemic.
More preparations have been made in Asia to respond to human cases of avian influenza, as opposed to cases of the disease in birds, especially in the past year.
Vietnam has a comprehensive plan that covers how government agencies responsible for everything from finance to tourism would respond to an epidemic.
Japan has begun manufacturing its own Tamiflu, a costly antiviral medicine that until recently was made only in Europe.
Hong Kong is assembling a database of private doctors willing to do volunteer work in government hospitals in the event of an epidemic.
South Korea is one of several governments in the region that has run an elaborate simulation for how government agencies might respond to a wide outbreak of the disease.
They had this huge operations room, video links and they had clips of news broadcasts by actual broadcasters.
Many of the gaps lie in differences in incomes among Asian countries.
Very poor countries like Cambodia and Laos still struggle to provide even the most basic health care to people outside their biggest cities.

Health officials worry that if the bird flu virus, A(H5N1) avian influenza, were to start spreading in either country, it could become entrenched and out of control before the international health community even became aware of it, quickly spreading across borders and around the globe.
Teams of experts from the WHO, the FAO and other U.N. agencies are scheduled to visit both countries later this year to assess their needs in fighting a possible pandemic and to provide advice.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
China's preparedness for fighting avian flu is something of a mystery.
Beijing authorities have announced that they have a draft plan to deal with a pandemic, but have divulged few details.

China's Agriculture Ministry has said that it is conducting extensive tests to identify sick animals and has found very few, but the availability of veterinary and medical care varies greatly from province to province and even within provinces.
Asia's most affluent societies have taken the greatest precautions.
Hong Kong, for example, has a health system that by some measures, like infant mortality rates and longevity of citizens, is better than the American system.

In Hong Kong, more than 100 private and state-run clinics, and most of the territory's nursing homes and child care centers, now provide the government with detailed, weekly reports on the number of fever cases and other illnesses, said Dr.Ronald Lam, the principal medical officer for emergency preparedness at the Hong Kong Health Department.

Some of the most elaborate preparations are under way in Taiwan, which has diplomatic relations with only 26 small nations, mostly in Africa, the South Pacific and the Caribbean, and worries that it might be cut off in a pandemic.
Taiwan was not only one of the earliest buyers of a national Tamiflu stockpile two years ago, but also set up its own small vaccine factory this summer.

The factory will manufacture 200,000 doses of an experimental vaccine created by Taiwanese scientists against the avian flu virus from genetically altered strains supplied by British and American laboratories, said Dr.Kou Hsu-sung, the director general of Taiwan's Center for Disease Control.
The doses will not be used even in safety or clinical trials.
They will be kept ready for a possible pandemic in which almost any vaccine, however untested, may be used.
So far, the virus has killed more than half of those infected.
If we cannot get the ones produced by the pharmaceutical companies, we will use ours in an emergency, Kou said.
And he said the Department of Health and Human Services has delayed completion of a national plan on how to respond to the pandemic.

HHS Secretary Michael Leavitt was in Vietnam on Friday as part of an Asian tour to discuss avian flu with international health officials and representatives of countries where a handful of human cases of H5N1 influenza have occurred.
His press representatives did not respond to Waxman's charges.
Health experts in and out of government have warned repeatedly in recent months of a possible pandemic of a new influenza strain for which there is little human resistance.

Confirmation this week that the H5N1 strain of avian influenza was found in poultry in Turkey heightened fears that this form of the disease may be about to mutate into a strain that can spread among humans.
Jeff Nesmith's e-mail address is jeffn@coxnews.com
U.N. HEALTH OFFICIALS FEAR AFRICA IS ALSO AT RISK FOR BIRD FLU

As bird flu has jumped this year from Southeast Asia to China, Russia, Kazakhstan and -- more recently -- into the Balkan region of Europe, scientists have become somewhat belatedly convinced that wild migratory birds are one of the main carriers of the dreaded H5N1 strain of avian influenza.

Although there is widespread anxiety about the arrival of bird flu in Europe -- European Union health ministers will convene a special session on Thursday to discuss the problem -- the next stops on bird migratory pathways are not in Western Europe, but in the Middle East, North Africa and East Africa itself, United Nations, officials here say.

Countries and farmers in these parts of the world, particularly in East Africa, are completely unprepared, lacking both the money and scientific infrastructure to control outbreaks of the virus, the U.N. officials said.
If the disease touches down there, it could well become widespread in the environment and on farms before it is even detected, he said.

Also, because in poorer African nations people live in close proximity with animals, such a situation would provide a dangerous crucible for the mixing or the bird and human viruses, vastly increasing the risk that the avian virus could gain the ability to readily spread among humans.
The close proximity between people and animals and insufficient surveillance and disease control capability in eastern African countries create an ideal breeding ground for the virus, Domenech said.

While H5N1 bird flu does not readily infect humans or spread between them, scientists fear that it could acquire that ability through biological mixing processes by which viruses can exchange genes if they are close together.
If the H5N1 strain were capable of spreading from man to man, they say, it could be the source of a devastating human flu pandemic.
In developed nations, bird flu outbreaks are controlled by aggressive public health measures.

Once the virus is suspected -- usually signaled by unusual bird deaths -- it is then stamped out by a combination of preventive culls and quarantines, even before the actual presence of the virus is confirmed.
Confirmation of H5N1 often takes a few days, since bird specimens must be sent to a specialized reference lab for typing.

In Macedonia, for example, health authorities were killing 10,000 birds in a small southern village Wednesday as they waited for tests to be performed in England, to confirm that the H5N1 strain was involved.
Another possible outbreak was reported in the Tula region in Russian, just west of the Urals.
In response to the first large-scale bird flu outbreak, in Hong Kong in late 1997, one million birds were killed in a day to stop the disease.
But such a procedure, which is extremely effective at controlling bird flu, would be difficult to perform in Africa, U.N. officials said.
Farmers have to report suspicious deaths quickly to the health authorities, who need to be poised for immediate investigation and killing.
Mandatory culls are problematic in poor countries, where a family's chickens are often not just a commercial product, but also a crucial source of family food.
The deadly strain of avian influenza is widespread in Southeast Asia.
But compliance with culls has sometimes been difficult in poorer parts of the region.
Poor farmers may choose not to report deaths for fear of loosing their bird.
Worse still, they may simply slaughter sick birds before health authorities confiscate them, in order to eat the birds or to sell them at local markets.
Eating meat from birds infected with the virus is not dangerous, since it is not a food-borne illness and dies with cooking.
But touching the birds may infect humans, who can get bird flu with close contact.
More worrisome, transport of sick bird or their carcasses to markets may infect other birds, spreading the animal pandemic, and making a human one ever more likely.
The virus persists for at least a short while on feathers and eggshells.
The United Nations will help countries in Africa strengthen surveillance, Domenech said.
But the international community will also have to help poor countries compensate farmers for their losses when their animals are killed, so that they will be willing to report and comply.
Domenech stressed that the bird flu risk due to wild bird is still relatively low.
But if the disease is established in Africa, it is likely to come to Europe next spring as the bird return north for the summer.

Although there is widespread anxiety about the arrival of bird flu in Europe -- EU Health Ministers will convene a special session on Thursday to discuss the problem -- the next stops on bird migratory pathways are not in western Europe, but in the Middle East, North Africa and East Africa, U.N. officials here say.

'NAIVE' IMMUNE SYSTEMS MAKE AVIAN FLU A MAJOR THREAT
Cox News Service
? WASHINGTON - The fear that the A/H5N1 avian flu could kill millions of people is based on the simple fact that very few people have ever had an influenza virus like this one - a situation immunologists call naivete."
?Mostly, avian flu does the same things to the body as its cousin, the flu that causes annual epidemics in the United States and other countries - it just does them worse.
But human immune systems can fight back against the annual flu because they have leftover antibodies and killer cells from previous bouts of illness or vaccinations.

These disease fighters are less than perfect, because each year's flu is slightly different, but they fight a sort of holding action while the body produces new antibodies and killer cells specifically tailored to the current strain.
In the case of avian flu, the immune system is faced with a disease unlike anything it has ever encountered and is unable to react quickly enough to fight off the swarming virus.

? "With a flu you've never seen before you're at much higher risk of having severe disease, because you don't recognize it at all," said Andrew MacGinnitie, an immunologist at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.
? "It takes a couple of weeks to generate your own antibody response to the new virus.
Unfortunately, it can kill you in that time," he added.
? When it infects chickens and other birds, influenza virus concentrates in the digestive track, but in humans it concentrates on cells in the airways and lungs.
? A cell inside the lungs is doomed as soon as the virus invades it.
The cell is forced to produce more virus, then it basically bursts, releasing vast numbers of new virus particles to invade other cells.
? Without effective immune system opposition, dead cells accumulate in the lungs.
At the same time, injured lung tissue starts to leak fluids.
? "So far in the cases of people who have caught H5N1 from birds," MacGinnitie said, "at some point your lungs stop working and you die."

? There is one major difference between pandemic flu and seasonal influenza, and it may explain why the 1918 "Great Influenza" pandemic took a disproportionate number of lives among young and seemingly healthy individuals.
? The 1918 pandemic, caused by a virus that has been designated H1N1, was the last time the world has faced a completely new form of influenza, health experts say.
? Seasonal flu epidemics - and pandemics that occurred in 1957 and 1967 - have been most severe among very young children and elderly people.
? But about half of the 1918 victims were between 18 and 44, said Michael Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota.
? He thinks the reason for this was a deadly immune system paradox that could happen again.
It is called "cytokine storm."

? Confronted with a strange new virus against which it has no effective antibodies, the immune system goes into a kind of biochemical panic and floods the lungs with other disease-fighting substances.
Before the virus has destroyed enough cells to interfere with the lungs' function, the patient suffocates on his own immune system chemistry.
?"The immune system sees this virus that it has never seen before, and it just goes bananas," said Laurie Garrett, a health writer and fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.
(Story can end here.
Optional add follows.)
?Although MacGinnitie said he also worries about cytokine storm, he disputes reports that more than half of the people who have contracted "bird flu" in Asia have died.
? Last week, the World Health Organization reported that of 118 confirmed cases in which the virus had "jumped" from birds to humans, 61 victims had died.
?"If you're in Asia and you work on a poultry farm, you probably would have to be near death before you would go to a hospital," he said.
? If one-third of all Americans became ill in a pandemic, that would be about 100 million cases.
If one in 200 died, that would be 500,000 deaths.
? Annual flu epidemics typically kill 35,000 Americans.
