SALT LAKE CITY GETS RAVES FOR ITS GAMES

SALT LAKE CITY - Despite a skating scandal and contentious press conferences, despite stringent security and occasional charges of overcommercialism, the Salt Lake 2002 Olympic Games may be remembered in coming months and years as the best in winter history.
And that is an upset almost as big as Sarah Hughes winning the women's skating gold.

Barring a terror attack today, the final day of the games, or a rash of positive doping cases, or a particularly virulent outbreak of bad sportsmanship, Salt Lake 2002 will end on a roll, an Olympics that ran like a well-oiled machine.
But a machine with a soul.
``I've been to Olympics where everything went off like clockwork,'' said Bonny Warner, who has been to every Winter Games since 1980 as a volunteer, athlete or television commentator.
The efficiency of Salt Lake 2002 sometimes has been obscured by questionable judging.
But in the long term, the skillful execution of the XIXth Winter Olympiad likely will set the standard for subsequent organizers.
All that is left is for International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge, overseeing his first Closing Ceremonies tonight, to put the IOC stamp of excellence on Salt Lake 2002.
His predecessor, Juan Antonio Samaranch, typically praised each Olympics (with the notable exception of Atlanta 1996) as ``the best-organized games ever.''
If Rogge follows in Samaranch's footsteps, it seems unavoidable that Salt Lake 2002 will gain the ``best-ever'' distinction, and deserve it.
Two years ago, success here seemed anything but a sure thing.
The Salt Lake Organizing Committee was mired in a vote-buying scandal going back to the 1995 IOC decision to return the Winter Olympics to the United States.
One key venue, the Utah Olympic Oval, was behind schedule in construction.
Enthusiasm in Utah for the Olympics was flagging.
Then came Sept. 11, and fears of an Olympics bloodied by terror.
Some suggested the games be canceled, or moved.
SLOC seemed to lose momentum again.

But under the leadership of SLOC President and CEO Mitt Romney, the organizing committee righted itself after the scandal and reoriented itself after 9-11 and showed the world's athletes a great time.

When the crowd files out of Rice-Eccles Stadium tonight at the end of Closing Ceremonies, Salt Lake 2002 will have sold in excess of 1.5 million tickets, taken in more than $180 million in ticket revenue and handled more than 70,000 visitors to its venues each day.
Records for a Winter Games.

Obscure (to Americans) sports such as biathlon and cross-country skiing will have been seen by crowds in excess of 10,000, and mainstream sports such as skating and hockey will have played to capacity audiences night after night -- at state-of-the-art venues.
Certainly, the competition has been memorable.

This was the Olympics that American multiculturalism made its mark in the Winter Games, with bobsledder Vonetta Flowers gaining the first gold medal by an African-American and speedskater Parra the first gold by a Mexican-American.
Speedskater Jennifer Rodriguez became the first Cuban-American to win a medal.
Ole Einar Bjoerndalen won four gold medals, in biathlon and cross-country skiing, leaving him one short of Eric Heiden's record five golds in 1980.
Janica Kostelic of Croatia became the first Alpine skier, male or female, to win four medals, three gold, at a single games.
Unassuming Jochem Uytdehaage set three world records and won three medals in speedskating.
There were great stories and great comments.
You knew who the major sponsors here were, but you weren't beaten over the head with their logos.
Foreign complaints about American corporate culture seemed muted.
Important, too, was the unobtrusive role the Mormon church took in Salt Lake 2002.
Utah is 70 percent Mormon, and there were fears before the games that Mormon mores on caffeine and alcohol would be forced down the throats of visitors, and tracts forced into their hands.
That never developed, and Mormonism was confined, to most visitors, to Tabernacle Square.
Certainly, Salt Lake 2002 had its low points.
There was the skate judging scandal that obscured other developments for almost a week.
There were traffic jams, early on, at some of the Alpine venues.
And a case can be made that SLOC spending $1.3 billion on these games was too much for 17 days of competition.
But in the grand scheme of things, Salt Lake 2002 worked better than anyone had a right to expect.
It gave the world a grand party in times of global anxiety and doubt.
X X X
Was that underrated underdog Sarah Hughes or underrated underdog Tom Brady?
China speed skater Yang Yang A or China speed skater Yang Yang S?
A controversial judging scam in figure skating or a controversial voting scam in college football's BCS?
Americans might have been confused by what they were watching during the Winter Olympics, but there's no uncertainty that they indeed were watching.
The Salt Lake Games and NBC's coverage had serious hiccups, but neither scandals nor shameless patriotism prevented viewers from tuning in at record levels.

Even before Sunday's prestigious men's U.S.-Canada hockey final and the Closing Ceremonies were factored in, NBC's coverage enjoyed an average 19.0 rating, a 15 percent increase from the '98 Nagano Games on CBS.
Furthermore, during its 17-day coverage NBC won every hour of prime-time ratings with 23 percent more viewers than CBS, ABC and Fox combined.
It also chose to run a seemingly nightly feature about the U.S. team's snappy berets, which _ just coincidentally _ are available for purchase on nbcolympics.com.
NBC's cameras and commentators, however, used pristine pictures and words to tell the stories of the most-watched Winter Olympics in history.

With events such as snowboarding and skeleton and a younger, more hip slant on prime-time programming with performances by 'N Sync, the Salt Lake Games drew a 23 percent increase in male viewers ages 18-34 over the Nagano Games.
As expected, women's figure skating was the Games' marquee event, drawing a 26.8 rating for Thursday's surprising victory by Hughes over Michelle Kwan.
That event drew the largest Thursday night TV audience for any network show since NBC's ``Seinfeld'' finale May 14, 1998.
Hockey was also a ratings winner, with the U.S.-Russia men's semifinal Friday drawing the largest Olympic cable audience ever.
Overall, about 84 percent of all U.S. television households tuned in to some part of NBC's coverage, a total of about 184 million.
``When you think that they [the United States] have 34 medals, when the most they've ever won is 13, that says a lot,'' Ebersol said.

``When the United States reached its low ebb with the Winter Games in Calgary in '88 and won only six medals, it was his commission that really locked the USOC into making sure that a significant amount of money was set aside to help athletes simply live during training.
That's made a pronounced difference in the way the U.S. medal count in the Winter Games has grown in recent years.''
Called a ``halo effect,'' NBC's Olympic coverage also strengthened its viewership across the network.
CNBC's ratings, for example, almost tripled, while MSNBC nearly quadrupled its audience.
Olympic programming helped power ``NBC Nightly News'' to its largest advantage over ABC News since the advent of people meters in 1987.
The ``Today'' show's lead over ``Good Morning America'' grew by 50 percent during the Games.

Also during the Olympics, NBC delivered a record Daytona 500 rating (10.9), the highest NBA All-Star Game rating (8.2) since '98 and its highest-rated NBA regular-season game (LA Lakers-Portland, 5.1) since '99.nn
CHINA PLANNING A MANNED SPACE MISSION FOR THIS YEAR

China plans to launch a manned capsule into orbit around Earth by the end of the year, accelerating a costly program designed to challenge American pre-eminence in space, official media reported on Thursday.

The mission would make China the third nation, after the United States and the former Soviet Union, to put people into orbit using rockets from its own program, a goal China has pursued since Mao Zedong began a space program in the early 1970s.
China's push to put an astronaut in space came as its unmanned Shenzhou IV spacecraft orbited Earth for a fourth day in what space program administrators said was a final dry-run for a manned flight.
Previously, officials said they expected to put an astronaut in orbit by 2005.
``Shenzhou V will be manned,'' the head of the Shanghai Aerospace Institute, Yuan Jie, said in official news reports.
European nations and Japan have developed commercial vehicles for launching satellites but have not pushed ahead for full-fledged space programs.
China also has ambitions for developing new industries in space and putting astronauts on the Moon and Mars.
NASA has not said when it intends to send a manned mission to Mars.
China's preparation for manned space flight has been intensive.
China sent astronauts to train in Russia in 1996 and has recently prepared at least a dozen people for space travel at a secret facility.
The Shenzhou spacecraft are converted Soviet space capsules from the 1960s that China says can carry people into orbit and return safely.
On previous missions of the Shenzhou, or ``divine mission,'' vehicles, China sent a dog, a rabbit, snails and mannequins into space.

The latest Shenzhou craft, which blasted off from the Jiuquan space center in the Gobi desert just after midnight on Monday, carried life-support equipment and other facilities needed for human beings, the government said.
Most details about China's space program are considered state secrets, reflecting military sponsorship.
The government does not announce dates for missions, and the state-controlled news media report on them only if they are successful.
But the Communist Party has promoted its space program as evidence of rising technological prowess and has used it to stir up patriotic feelings.

State media have also begun to extol China's astronauts, anonymous pilots culled from China's air force, in a way reminiscent of the enthusiasm that surrounded the buildup to the U.S. Apollo missions in the 1960s.
It remains uncertain when he will leave that post.
China has lifted payloads into orbit since the first Long March rocket took off in 1970.
Since then, China has completed nearly 75 launchings and has sold satellite-launching services to Western companies for a decade.
But the program has also hit rough patches.
The Long March rockets have had about a dozen failures.
A rocket with an American-made telecommunications satellite aboard exploded on takeoff in 1995, killing six people on the ground.
The following year another rocket put a $120 million Chinese satellite into the wrong orbit, rendering it useless.
CHINESE SPACE EFFORT CHALLENGES RUSSIA AND U.S.
Even as the United States and Russia grow cautious about the cost of exploring other worlds, China is taking the first steps to challenging their longtime pre-eminence in space.

Beijing plans to launch a manned capsule into orbit around Earth by the end of the year, speeding up an effort intended to showcase its growing technological abilities and to take advantage of the scientific, military and commercial potential of space.

The launching would make China the third nation, after the United States and the former Soviet Union, to put astronauts into orbit using its own rockets, a goal China has pursued since Mao Zedong began a space program in the early 1970s.
Chinese space program officials are describing the current flight of the Shenzhou IV, an unmanned craft, as a final dry run for the manned flight.
Shenzhou IV is in its fourth day orbiting Earth.
Officials had previously said they did not expect to put an astronaut into orbit until 2005.
Europe and Japan have developed commercial launching vehicles for satellites but have not built full-fledged space programs.
China also has ambitions of developing new industries in space and putting people on both the moon and Mars.
NASA has not said when it intends to pursue a Mars mission.
It remains uncertain when he will leave that post.
Preparations for manned space flight have been intensive.
China sent astronauts to train in Russia in the 1990s and has recently prepared at least a dozen people for space travel at a secret facility outside Beijing.
The Shenzhou spacecraft are converted Soviet capsules from the 1960s that China says can carry people into orbit and return safely.
On previous launchings of the Shenzhou, or ``divine mission,'' vehicles, China sent a dog, a rabbit, snails and dummy astronauts.
The Shenzhou IV, which blasted off from the Jiuquan space center in the Gobi Desert just after midnight on Monday, carried life-support equipment for human beings, the government said.
Most details about China's space program are kept secret.
But the Communist Party has also promoted it as evidence of rising technological prowess.
Official media have begun to extol China's astronauts in a way reminiscent of enthusiasm for the Apollo missions in the 1960s.
AFTER ASTRONAUT'S SUCCESS, CHINA VOWS QUICK RETURN TO SPACE

Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a space lab or space station.
The swift commitment underscored the confidence and enthusiasm infused into the space program by the Shenzhou 5 mission, which established China as the third nation to send a human into space.
He was quickly flown to Beijing, where he passed a physical examination.
Later in the day, in an interview on state television, he described the wonders of space and also what he had not seen.
``But I did not see the Great Wall.''
Zhou Xiaofei, the director of manned space engineering, said at a news conference that China had busy space plans in coming years, including a another piloted Shenzhou mission within a year or two.
He listed the immediate priorities as, in order, space walking, mastering the docking of space vehicles and e1tablishing a space lab.
``Our plans are in their first stages,'' he said of a space lab.
``The space lab won't be anything like Mir or the International Space Station.''
In addition, Chinese officials plan within three years to begin orbiting and exploring the moon sidj unpiloted probes and to build a Hubble-like space telescope.
There is talk of a Mars mission one day.
The government also offered a rare glimpse into its budget.
Western estimates of China's space budget are typically about $2 billion a year.

The government now says its program for humans in space, including the first four unpiloted launchings, has cost roughly $2.2 billion, which would seem remarkably low by American or European standards, but China has a reputation for being thrifty, and costs are lower here.
``The United States and Russia are much more experienced than we are, and we're quite willing to learn from them,'' Xie said, according to a report by the official news media.
Washington has been wary of space partner{harted their future, other officials were already cranking up their public relations efforts.
The government will print 10.2 million sets of commemorative stamps in honor of the mission, and Yang has already become as visible on television as President Hu Jintao.
It is hard, though, to gauge the depth of public enthusiasm for the mission and how much domestic good will it will generate for the government.
Many people interviewed at random in Beijing and Shanghai had never heard of the Shenzhou 5.
But many others had followed developments closely and expressed deep pride that China was maturing into a technological power.
EDITORIAL OBSERVER: WHAT CHINA'S FIRST MAN IN SPACE SHOULD LEARN

I don't know how many of them remain, but when I was a correspondent in the Soviet Union in the 1980s, there wasn't a single city, town or even village across the entire 11 time zones that didn't havd e Gagarin Street.
Many also had Gagarin Squares, quite a few had Gagarin Institutes or Gagarin Schools, and many had Gagarin statues.
No Soviet figure, except the deified Lenin, was more exalted in the Soviet firmament than Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space.
A major part of his allure for the creators of official myths, of course, was that he was not a political figure, `n` so not subject to retroactive debunking, like every Soviet ruler after Lenin.
I mulled all this as I followed the brief odyssey of Lt.Col.Yang Liwei, the first man sent into space by China.
That's not the only difference, of course.
Spaceflight was still the stuff of Jules Vernu how that flight stunned America.
It was the peak of the Cold War, when every ``first'' symbolized ideological and technological supremacy.
Three and a half years earlier, the Kremlin had sent up the first satellite, and now the first man.
``Let the capitalist countries try to catch up,'' Nikita Khrushchev said, gloating in the Kremlin.
There will be military implications to ponder but, to be frank, it is hard to get too excited.
Still, I can't help suspecting that the Communist rulers in Beijing launched Yang into space for many of the same reasons that the Kremlin sent Gagarin up.

Authoritarian regimes are forever in search of spectacular displays to assert their greatness and legitimacy, and to divert people from whatever subversive complaints and frustrations they may harbor.
The vast squares, grandiose monuments, huge demonstrations and endless self-praise are as much a fixture of these regimes as secrecy and intolerance.
China's rulers probably expect some tangible economic and military benefits from manned flight, but I would bet that their primary hope is to lift their standing at home and with the world.
Apart from the deja vu of it all, they might ponder what good it did the Soviet state or Gagarin.

He was killed in a jet fighter accident just seven years after his spaceflight, and, in the peculiar fate Russians reserved for official heroes of Soviet propaganda, his legend was systematically taken apart piece by piece in the streets.
According to ``firm'' reports, he crashed because he was drunk, or because he was trying to shoot deer from his MiG, or because he had smuggled a woman into his cockpit.
However personable or heroic he may really have been, entry into the Soviet propaganda pantheon spelled death in the streets.
He seems a decent type, and I will always be in awe, and jealous, of anyone who can say what Gagarin said: ``I can observe Earth . . .
One can see everything.
'' It has to change your life, no matter how often it is done.
That's something Yang will want to hold onto, so perhaps he should ask President Hu Jintao and the others to build their statues to themselves.

The photographs of American soldiers smiling, laughing and signaling ``thumbs up'' as Iraqi detainees were forced into sexually humiliating positions provoked outrage just as the American military was seeking to pacify a rising insurgency and gain the trust of more Iraqis before turning over sovereignty to a new government on June 30.

Karpinski, who has returned to South Carolina and her civilian profession as a business consultant, said she visited Abu Ghraib as often as twice a week last fall and had repeatedly instructed military police officers under her command to treat prisoners humanely and in accord with international human rights agreements.

She stressed that she had received no reports from any of her commanders of possible prisoner abuses in the cellblock.

After the first allegations of abuse circulated earlier this year, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S.Sanchez, the senior American commander in Iraq, ordered sweeping inquiries into whether any commanders _ including Karpinski _ should be held responsible.
He also ordered a review of policies and procedures at all of the prisons controlled by occupation forces in Iraq.

The administrative review, known in the military criminal justice system as an AR15-6, was completed March 1 by Army Maj.Gen.Antonio M. Taguba, who had assembled a team of officers trained in military detention.
The report was approved by his superior, Lt. Gen. David D.McKiernan, commander of American ground forces in the Middle East, and forwarded to Sanchez on April 4.
The finding documented the abuses illustrated by the photographs circulating last week, as well as other problems in the military's detainee system in Iraq.
SOLDIERS NOT SOLELY TO BLAME IN ABUSE, GENERAL CA[

The New Yorker magazine said in its new edition that the report by Maj. Gen. Antonio M.Taguba found that reservist military police at the prison were urged by Army military officers and CIA agents to ``set physical and mental conditions for favorable interrogation of witnesses.''

According to the New Yorker article, the Army report offered accounts of rampant and gruesome abuse from October to December of 2003 that included the sexual assault of an Iraqi detainee with a chemical light stick or broomstick.

While reports of abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American and British soldiers have come to light in the last several days, the report cited by The New Yorker indicates a far more wide-ranging and systematic pattern of cruelties than previously reported.

COMMENTARY
The prison complex at Abu Ghraib earned a nightmarish reputation under former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein.
Now it appears an unknown number of American solders have ensured the prison's reputation outlived the regime.

While the vast majority of uniformed personnel in Iraq carry out their duties with professionalism and restraint, those who commit acts such as this undermine the mission in Iraq and harm America's international reputation.
The United States must not tolerate these acts and must ensure such violations do not occur as it again works to build confidence in its activities in Iraq.
Most citizens are now familiar with the images of sadistic cruelty of Iraqi prisoners in Abu Ghraib.

However, they may not be familiar with the 53-page internal military report written by Maj. Gen. Antonio M.Taguba, published last week in The New Yorker, that outlines the extent of the transgressions.
In stomach-turning detail, the report catalogues the physical, mental and sexual abuse perpetrated on Iraqi prisoners, and names those believed responsible for the torture.

Now, the top U.S. commander in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S.Sanchez, has recommended the most severe reprimand for the six supervisors of the pris the reassignment of Brig. Gen. Janis Karpild seem important steps toward apportioning blame for the despicable acts at Abu Ghraib.
Yet, troubling questions Remqin.

One enlisted man charged in the abuse, Staff Sgt.Ivan Frederick, says he was instructed to ``soften up'' the detainees as preparation for questioning by military intelligenbe* Gen.Karpinski, has made similar protestations, claiming that reservists are taking a fall for active-duty soldiers and military intelligence's instructions.
If the Taguba report can be trusted, the abuse occurred, without repercussion, between October and December, and was not stopped until late January.
President Bush already says an investigation is under way, but he also seems comfortable in attributing these acts to a few misguided soldiers.
Yet, if this is a chain-of-command failure as some details suggest a more thorough investigation will be needed to prevent future abuses.
The claims made by Frederick and Karpinski suggest the problem is more endemic and will require concerted effort to resolve.
These acts have harmed the American mission in Iraq.
U.S. soldiers may face more intense resistance on the ground and international opinion is again inflamed.
The only hope is that the repercussions of these events ensure such violations never occur again.

SOLDIER SENTENCED TO 8 YEARS IN PRISON FOR ROLE IN ABU GHRAIB ABUSES
A military court sentenced Staff Sgt.Ivan L. Frederick on Thursday to eight years in prison for abusing Iraqi prisoners last year in the grim chambers of Abu Ghraib.
It was the harshest sentence yet handed down in the abuse hearings, involving the highest-ranked enlisted soldier of the eight charged in the scandal.
Two others have been convicted.
The judge, Col.James A. Pohl, also reduced Frederick's rank to private, and ordered him dishonorably discharged.
The sergeant was originally sentenced to 10 years in prison, but that term was reduced to eight years through a plea bargain that also calls for forfeiture of pay.
The bargain requires Frederick to cooperate in the pending cases.
Frederick pleaded guilty to eight counts of abusing detainees at Abu Ghraib prison, 15 miles west of Baghdad, in October and November of 2003.

In court, he described in graphic detail how he forced Arab prisoners to masturbate, punched a hooded prisoner and attached wires to another standing on a flimsy box who was made to believe he would be
